title.english: Lady Oscar: The Rose of Versailles

description:
Raised from birth as a man, the Lady Oscar commands the palace guards at Versailles in the years before the French Revolution. Her beauty and noble spirit make her a shining figure in the eyes of both men and women but she is torn between her chosen life of service and duty to class and country and her own heart and desires. She lives as a noble amidst the opulence of Versailles but her keen senses and compassion are not blinded to the poverty of the French people.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Class Struggle
tags.description: Contains conflict born between the different social classes. Generally between an dominant elite and a suffering oppressed group.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Royal Affairs
tags.description: Features nobility, alliances, arranged marriage, succession disputes, religious orders and other elements of royal politics.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Shoujo
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult females.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Ojou-sama
tags.description: Features a wealthy, high-class, oftentimes stuck up and demanding female character.

tags.name: Crossdressing
tags.description: Prominently features a character dressing up as the opposite sex.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Gender Bending
tags.description: Prominently features a character who dresses and behaves in a way characteristic of another gender, or has been transformed into a person of another gender.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Time Skip
tags.description: Features a gap in time used to advance the story.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Maids
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a maid.

tags.name: LGBTQ+ Themes
tags.description: Prominently features characters or themes associated with the LGBTQ+ community, such as sexuality or gender identity.

tags.name: Religion
tags.description: Centers on the belief that humanity is related to supernatural, transcendental, and spiritual elements.

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

node.description:
Ikeda made her debut in 1967 with [Bara Yashiki no Shoujo](https://anilist.co/manga/111369/Bara-Yashiki-no-Shoujo) in Shoujo Friend when she still was a philosophy student. She was the first to pick up a historic theme in her highly acclaimed [Versailles no Bara](https://anilist.co/manga/30660/Versailles-no-Bara) and did other impressive historical works. She is part of the Year 24 Group. 

It's rumored she had an affair with a politician and Ikeda disappeared from the manga-scene around the mid-80's. However she returned at the end of 1998 again with [Orpheus no Mado Gaiden](https://anilist.co/manga/94262/Orpheus-no-Mado-Gaiden).  

In 2008, Ikeda received France's Ordre national de la Légion d'honneur.
Performed Maya the Bee's Theme Song in French version.

Was a fan of Le Mans.

Dezaki was known for his distinct visual style, which makes use of split screen, stark lighting, extensive use of dutch angle, and pastel freeze frames that he called "postcard memories", which may be his most famous trademark.

Younger brother of director [Satoshi Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/111371). He is married to the mangaka [Rikako Kugayama](https://anilist.co/staff/304119).

Non-anime staff credits:~!
Animation director for "The Visionaries" (US cartoon)
Animation for "Rainbow Brite" (US cartoon)!~

Araki developed an interest for drawing at age five. He graduated in Aichi Prefecture. In 1955, at age eighteen, he debuted as a cartoonist in the "Machi" magazine. He then joined Mushi Production as animator in 1964 and later founded Studio Jaccard in 1966. In 1970, he debuted as animation director on [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), and later worked on the anime adaptations of several of [Gou Nagai](https://anilist.co/staff/97992/)'s manga, including [Devilman](https://anilist.co/anime/2252/), [Cutie Honey](https://anilist.co/anime/1661/), and [UFO Robo Grendizer](https://anilist.co/anime/1985/), serving as a character designer on the latter two. In 1971 he founded Studio Z together with his friends in the business.

He frequently worked with animator [Michi Himeno](https://anilist.co/staff/113357/), who he met in 1973. Araki formed Araki Production in 1974 and Himeno was the first member of the studio.

Araki was also an animator on several American productions which outsourced animation work to Japan, including Mighty Orbots (1984, key animation), The Adventures of the American Rabbit (1986) and G.I. Joe: The Movie (1987).

He passed away due to heart failure on December 1, 2011.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西久保瑞穂)

Husband of late voice actress [Yuuko Mizutani](https://anilist.co/staff/95485/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高屋敷英夫)

Formerly married to fellow scriptwriter [Tomoko Konparu](https://anilist.co/staff/103462).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/前田実)

Well-known for his work in the [Dragon Ball](https://anilist.co/anime/223/) series.

_Note: Not to be confused with [background artist](https://anilist.co/staff/219450/)._

After graduating from high school, Dezaki took a position at Toshiba while studying in the department of literature at Hosei University. While doing both of these, he continued to work on his dream job of working on movie production. He acted as the coach for the nine-member volleyball team at Toshiba. Dezaki also began pulling together an anime production team.

Dezaki resigned after working for seven years at Toshiba, leaving Hosei University in the middle of a term as well. He began working for [Gisaburou Sugii's](https://anilist.co/staff/103537) company Art Fresh, working alongside his younger brother [Osamu](https://anilist.co/staff/100393). His first works included writing the script for [Attack No.1](https://anilist.co/anime/1550) and storyboarding [Kyojin no Hoshi](https://anilist.co/anime/5834).

In 1969, Dezaki became a freelancer, doing scripting, production and direction work for [Tokyo Movie Shinsha](https://anilist.co/studio/65), [Tatsunoko Production](https://anilist.co/studio/103), and [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14). In 1977, he founded [Magic Bus](https://anilist.co/studio/207) and produced and animated [Shin Kyojin no Hoshi](https://anilist.co/anime/15875).

He is the older brother of [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393), and the husband of [Setsuko Shibuichi](https://anilist.co/staff/101935/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉川惣司)

A fan of [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s works, when Yoshikawa was a sophomore in high school, he saw a "Mushi Production's first batch of animators wanted" news article and applied for the job, which led him to enter the anime industry. He was planning to go to art college, but was invited to join Mushi Pro, so he quit high school and joined the company. He participated as an animator for the first [Astro Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/) series. In 1967, he participated in the founding of _Art Fresh with Gisaburou Sugii and Osamu Dezaki_. After working as an animator on Mushi Production's [Gokuu no Daibouken](https://anilist.co/anime/2687/), which Art Fresh participated in, he worked as a freelance animator before becoming a senior director and board member of Dyna-Method Inc.

In addition to serving as episode director, storyboard artist and writer, he also worked as a director. He has participated in [Tensai Bakabon](https://anilist.co/anime/6468/), [Star of the Giants](https://anilist.co/anime/5834/), [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), [Moomin](https://anilist.co/anime/8234/), [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/anime/1412/), [Invincible Super Man Zambot 3](https://anilist.co/anime/2200/), [Invincible Steel Man Daitarn 3](https://anilist.co/anime/3305/), and [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/).

In addition to anime, he created, wrote and directed Star Guardian with Airship Theater Company, wrote the screenplays for Tanoshii Moomin Ikka and Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs and wrote and directed The Wizard of Oz. It all started when he was asked by director [Masaaki Oosumi](https://anilist.co/staff/122102/) to help with the screenplay of Aladdin for Airship Theater Company's Aladdin when he was working on the TV adaptation of Moomin. In addition, he has worked on commercials, events, performances and novels. He has been a fan of science fiction since he read Shounen Shoujo Sekai Kagaku Bouken Zenshuu by Kodansha when he was a kid.

One of the reasons that the 100th episode of the [Kirby: Right Back at Ya!](https://anilist.co/anime/2390/) anime contained some problems, inconsistencies, and heavy-handedness in the plot and development is that Yoshikawa, who wrote the final episode, learned that his wife was in critical condition at the time and had to rush through the script and leave it in incomplete form in order to be present for her dying moments.

[Yasuo Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/136873/) cited in an interview for the Lupin III Perfect Book: Complete Collector's Edition, that [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/), Osamu Dezaki, and Yoshikawa as representative members of the Japanese anime world.

(Source: Wikipedia)
